9 NATIVK BBBD FOR WB8TERN NEBRASKA. I rainfall of Nebraska is 28 ta 'M inches in the east and illy itCMHtl lo 14 inches on the western border. This gNftl ■ cksafB in cliinatic conditions in going west (Hi miles from the Missouri river as is found in perhaps i> llif MMt. We sliould therefore expect a marked ncf in mi snitahle for the eastern and western parts of » ation of cooperative corn experiments. In both l!H>^ and limit, experiments in variety testing were < arried on in cooperation witli fanners in western Nebraska, It was known that varieties from east of the Missouri river could nc.i he e\pe< ted to give good results, so the varieties used were \ from eastern or central Nebraska, and thought to be fairlv well acclimatized. The experimenters were in each case I to include a test of their own corn or some good native \ariet\ under the same conditions. Not all included the native . irn in the test, and also not more than one-half of the experi - menters were able to return satisfactory reports, owing to various causes. A heavy snow occurring early in the fall of 1908 nted many from husking until midwinter, and others lo«t Hm entire crop from drouth, hail, or other causes. However, 21 experimenters made a satisfactory report in 1908, and 27 in 1909

13 lic concluded from this that it will be safer for western to us*- their native seed than to try importing seed even bi the eastern part of the state. Tti. i of local varieties Mattered thruout the western nd a can-fiil search should be made among i hem to find the \er\ Ust There is an excellent opportunity _:.i«iii^ of acclimated weai corn in western Nebraska. ti brought into a new region usually i proves in yield for • r more yean or presumably until acclimated. In here coin is moved from a dry climate or an un ■ilili- soil into more favorable conditions, good results are - iired from tin- first, but experimental data are noi able that would indicate how general this rule would be in sonic caaw where native corn has not been wisely ■ il. ■ food \arietv brought from a distance will often give rior ii'sults from the first, and improve in yield with time. There are also widely separated regions very similar in en mental conditions where an exchange of seed would prob ;iblv not affect \ it-Ids.
